84 Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer ^ Notes on elliptic curves,  II
§ 3.  Formulae for Lp ( l )
We have now to derive from ( 2.  7 ) an expression for Ljy ( s ) which can be analytically continued as far as = 1 and is such that Ljy ( i ) can be written in finite form.  Since the extra generality costs us nothing,  we shall assume only that Z ) is a Gaussian integer ; however,  the important case is when D is rational.  We may also assume that D is fourth- power free ; for multiplying D by a fourth power only changes finitely many factors in ( 2.  6 ), and changes those in an obvious way. 
We write D = EF,  where E = I mod ( 2 + 2i ) and F is the product of a power of 1 + i and a unit ; and we define Л to be the product of the distinct primes dividing Æ,  normalized so that A = I mod ( 2 + 2i ). If i ) is real,  so are E,  F and A.  For convenience we also write e — (— i / E )^^ so that e =^-{- liîE ^ l mod 4 and e = — 1 if £ = 3 + 2i mod 4.  Remembering that cr = 1 mod ( 2 - f 2i ) where a is the variable of summation in ( 2.  7 ), and using the law of quartic reciprocity,  we have
Here the first factor on the right only depends on the residue class of a modulo A,  and the second factor on the class of a modulo 16.  Let К be such that ( 2 - f 2i ) | £, that К I 16 and that ( еЕ / а )^^ depends only on the residue class of a modulo K,  ( We could take К = 16 always,  but a smaller value of К reduces the complexity of some of the later formulae and so also the time taken in computation.  We may for instance take £ = 8 if £ is real,  and £ = 4 if £ = ± 1. )
Now let £ be a set of representatives for the residue classes modulo zl,  and let С be a set of representatives for those residue classes mod К which are congnient to 1 mod ( 2 - f 2i ). We can write
